channel.title: BUbreakingSectionTwo
channel.description: This is a randomly ordered feed of the most recent entries from BUbreakingSectionTwo, skipping any feeds with errors.

item.title: A Nerve-Racking Week for SNAP Recipients, and Elon Musk’s $1 Trillion Pay Deal
Even as stocks slide, Wall Street is at ‘historically extreme valuations,’ warns Apollo chief economist
item.description: The latest data underlines a broader concern among analysts that a reckoning is looming for the markets.

item.title: Russian Sanctions Risk Straining Trump’s Chummy Relationship With Hungarian Leader
item.description: New U.S. penalties on Russian energy could be a sticking point as President Trump and Prime Minister Viktor Orban of Hungary meet.

item.title: Gen Alpha won’t ever have to write an email when they join the workforce, new research reveals—they’ll be sending voice notes to their boss instead
item.description: LSE researchers say Gen Alpha will talk, not type at work—they predict that voice notes will make keyboard practically obsolete by 2030.

item.title: Mark Zuckerberg says ‘The Social Network’ nailed his wardrobe: ‘Every single shirt or fleece they had in that movie is a shirt or fleece that I own’
item.description: Zuckerberg even bought one of the shirts worn by actor Jesse Eisenberg, on auction, for over $4,000.

item.title: As Saudi Arabia Cracks Down on Drugs, Executions Near a Record High
item.description: Facing an influx of amphetamines, the kingdom has put hundreds of people to death, many of them foreigners convicted of low-level smuggling.

item.title: Elon Musk’s $1 trillion pay package and the race to the bottom among states with weak corporate governance laws
item.description: Also: All the news and watercooler chat from Fortune.

item.title: As Hours Dwindled Before Flight Cuts, the Government Was Publicly Mum
item.description: Airlines did not wait for an announcement, notifying passengers and airports of expected changes before the Trump administration made official its lis...

item.title: Why Germany Is Still Divided When It Comes to Russia
item.description: Many East Germans are more sympathetic toward Moscow than their western compatriots, reflecting decades of Soviet ties and disillusionment since reuni...

item.title: How Macy’s, Dillard’s, and Nordstrom are getting their groove back
item.description: Department stores have a new playbook to win back shoppers from discount stores and Amazon.

item.title: 10 Years After the Paris Climate Agreement, Here's Where We Are
item.description: Has anything really changed in the decade since the Paris Agreement was reached? Actually, quite a lot.

item.title: Russian Sanctions Risk Straining Trump’s Chummy Relationship With Hungarian Leader
item.description: New U.S. penalties on Russian energy could be a sticking point as President Trump and Prime Minister Viktor Orban of Hungary meet.

item.title: Trump’s Tariffs Scar Canadian City Where Cars Have Been Made for Decades
item.description: An automaker’s decision to shift Canadian jobs to the United States has left workers in Brampton, Ontario, feeling betrayed and angry.

item.title: As Saudi Arabia Cracks Down on Drugs, Executions Near a Record High
item.description: Facing an influx of amphetamines, the kingdom has put hundreds of people to death, many of them foreigners convicted of low-level smuggling.

item.title: Why Germany Is Still Divided When It Comes to Russia
item.description: Many East Germans are more sympathetic toward Moscow than their western compatriots, reflecting decades of Soviet ties and disillusionment since reuni...
